awd_titl_txt: Molecular and Morphology Engineering of Non-Fullerene Organic Solar Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Organic solar photovoltaic cells are promising low cost, scalable, and sustainable solar energy based electrical power generation technologies.  Major innovations in semiconductor materials are needed to create energy conversion and energy storage devices based upon organic photovoltaics. This project aims to discover fundamental knowledge needed for creating organic semiconductor materials with improved properties and for designing more efficient organic solar cells. The project develops engineering strategies to design, synthesize, and process new materials with the aim of enhancing how they absorb light, generate charge, and transport charge through thin films and in devices. The project also provides opportunities for training future scientists and engineers, including women and underrepresented minorities in STEM, in the interdisciplinary fields of semiconductor materials, optoelectronic devices, and energy technologies. The project also enables improvements to the curriculum by integration of research findings into the graduate and undergraduate courses taught at the University of Washington. As part of this project, a symposium on solar energy frontier research will be organized for a future American Chemical Society or Materials Research Society meeting. Researchers involved in this project also will participate in a program organized by the Pacific Science Center of Seattle focusing on renewable energy and solar technologies.

Photovoltaic devices have generally been made by blending a p-type (donor) semiconducting polymer with an electron-conducting (acceptor) fullerene derivative. This project studies new non-fullerene acceptors that are expected to be more chemically, photochemically and mechanically rugged, more economical, and more readily manufactured on a large scale compared to their fullerene counterparts. The project also involves new morphology engineering approaches for understanding and achieving high performance non-fullerene organic solar cells. The following objectives are being pursued: (1) The design, synthesis, and characterization of a series of cyclopentaquinoxaline-based small-molecule, non-fullerene, acceptor materials; (2) The design, synthesis, and characterization of new amorphous wide bandgap p-type semiconducting copolymers with optimal properties suitable for high performance solar cells; and (3) The investigation of the morphology, photophysics, charge transport, charge recombination and photovoltaic properties of blends of the new acceptor materials with donor polymers.  The results of these studies will generate new fundamental understanding of light absorption and charge transport in n-type organic semiconductors and will provide new physical insights into charge photogeneration, transport, and collection in organic solar cells.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This research project aimed to address some of the basic scientific challenges and opportunities in the field of organic semiconductor materials used to develop organic solar cells, which are promising low-cost, scalable, and sustainable solar energy based electrical power generation technologies.

The overall goal of this project was to develop novel small-molecule electron acceptor materials and molecular engineering approaches for understanding and achieving high performance non-fullerene organic solar cells. Specifically, the proposed project aimed to accomplish the following objectives: (1) Design, synthesize, and characterize a series of novel small-molecule, non-fullerene acceptor materials for high performance organic photovoltaics; (2) Investigate the morphology, photophysics, charge transport, charge recombination and photovoltaic properties of blends of the new acceptor materials with suitable donor polymers; and (3) Develop a fundamental understanding of the underlying structure-property-device performance relationships in organic solar cells.

The scientific and technical advances made in this project have been documented in peer-reviewed journal publications and invited presentations at international conferences. Based on the research results of this project, two journal articles have been published to date and another three manuscripts are in preparation for publication. Among invited lectures presented include those at: Polymer Physics Prize Symposium 2021, American Physical Society (APS) March Meeting, Online, March 15-19, 2021; Int. Symposium on Frontiers in Conjugated Polymer Design & Synthesis, American Chemical Society (ACS) Spring National Meeting, Online, April 5-30, 2021; Materials Science and Engineering Workshop, American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, UAE, 2019; and Int. Symposium on Molecular Engineering, London, UK, 2019. A few specific findings and outcomes of the project are highlighted below.

We designed, synthesized, and characterized a novel class of small-molecule non-fullerene electron acceptors (NFAs) with enhanced electrochemical redox stability and found that they can be used to develop high performance polymer solar cells (Figure 1). The series of new bis(naphthalene imide)arylenelidenes (BNIAs) when paired with donor polymer PBDB-T had a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 11% with a Voc exceeding 1 V. Unlike the current state-of-the-art NFAs, which are exemplified by ITIC, which consists of a indacenodithieno[3,2-b]thiophene (IDTT) core end-capped with 1,1-dicyanomethylene-3-indanone (DCMI) acceptor moieties, our new BNIAs have excellent reversibility in their redox processes, implying enhanced intrinsic chemical stability. Furthermore, the rylene imide building blocks of the new BNIAs provide many avenues for the future fine-tuning of their electronic structures and optimization of their photovoltaic properties. The results have been published in Chemistry of Materials.

We investigated a major current fundamental concern with the intrinsic (chemical, electrochemical and photochemical) stability of state-of-the-art NFAs, that have a methine-bridged acceptor-donor-acceptor architecture, which are synthesized by Knoevenagel condensation and is implicated in their possible instability. Our results show that the α,β-unsaturated Knoevenagel compounds possess high chemical instability and reactivity that have been overlooked, suggesting broad implications for all ITIC-like NFAs and strongly suggest that new approaches are needed to enhance intrinsic stability.

Among the broader impact activities enabled by this project include the service of the PI on the Strategic Advisory Board of the Institute of Molecular Engineering and Sciences at Imperial College, London and on the Editorial Advisory Boards of several international journals, including Materials Chemistry Frontiers and Research. This project also enabled research collaborations with international research groups in Sweden, Japan, and South Korea. In conjunction with the Clean Energy Institute (CEI) at the University of Washington, graduate students Sarah West and Duyen Tran have been involved in multiple outreach activities in Seattle metropolitan and its suburbs, including the Pacific Science Center?s Climate Change Curiosity Expo and the annual Enumclaw School Foundation?s interactive science, technology, engineering, art, and mathematics (iSTEAM) expo. The goals of these outreach activities are to raise the general public awareness of clean energy sources, smart grids, and energy storage systems as well as to engage students in science and engineering concepts by hands-on activities.

During the three-year duration of this project, our lab provided undergraduate research experience for a total of 7 students, including 4 female and three underrepresented minority students. Of these, two female students (Koto Durkee and Isabel Gjerde) and a male student (Gage Elerding) had year-long undergraduate research experience in our lab.

The funding of this project enabled the direct training of a total of 3 graduate students pursuing PhD degrees in chemistry and chemical engineering. One of these, Xiaomei Ding (Figure 2), completed her PhD in chemistry degree in June 2021 while the others are at various stages of completing their degrees. This project involved the design, synthesis, and characterization of the multi-scale structural, optical and charge transport properties of small-molecule, non-fullerene acceptor materials as well as the fabrication and evaluation of organic photovoltaic cells. The graduate students involved have had the opportunity to develop research skills and expertise in these areas.

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2021
Modified by: Samson A Jenekhe

Images (1 of )

    Samson A. Jenekhe
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Samson A Jenekhe
    Structures of 3 new electron acceptor molecules synthesized.
  • Figure 2. Project graduate student, Xiaomei Ding, who completed her PhD in chemistry in June 2021.
    Xiaomei Ding, University of Washington
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Samson A Jenekhe
    Picture of female graduate student who received the PhD in chemistry in June 2021.
